I posted this here because the question is a scientific one and not a social one...not interested in who thinks same-sex marriages is socially acceptable on moral grounds.
 
 I'm interested in knowing why you think there are homosexuals in nature and what effect they will have on the overall human population.
 
 What is the scientific reason why nature would create beings who are incapable of reproducing with each other?
 
 Is there a scientific reason for people being attracted to the same sex?
 
 If it is caused by a genetic mutation, these genes cannot be passed on if there is no reproduction -unless these genes are mated with a heterosexual.
 
 Is it possible, that over time, there could be only homosexuals left, who can't reproduce, and in time the human race will become extinct?

Some anthropologists have suggested that grown men with ties only to each other and to their tribe may have been useful for defence.
 
 As for a genetic cause of homosexuality leading to its elimination I don't see that happening. Current theories of male homosexuality indicate that a genetic cause is likely to be carried in the female line (i.e. on one X chromosome) but only exhibit in men. As In understand it, colour blindness is similar.

 How many situations like this have been documented throughout history? I can think of only 1 at the most: Sparta, which was always a militaristic society before the advent of Alexander the Great. However, Sodomy was found in all upper-crust Greek cities- not just Sparta. So the military connection is slim at best.

Even with the sequencing of the human genome I have yet to hear about the discovery of any gene that controls complex behavior like sex. If there is a genetic basis for sex, it would likely involve multiple genes acting together.
 
 But if sexual orientation were to be controlled by a single gene or by a collection of genes that act as if they were a single gene because they are inherited as a group because they are on the same chromosome (and assuming that no chromosomal rearrangement takes place during meiosis), genes for sexual orientation would follow Mendel's laws and the Hardy-Weinberg law, and the predicted outcome of these laws is not supported by real world data from the human population.
 
 In Mendelian genetics genes are either dominant, recessive or co-dominant in their phenotype, although genes for single traits (eye color or blood type for example) can have multiple forms with each distinct form being dominant, recessive or co-dominant to the other forms. But genes for any given trait exist in two distinct forms as far as their genotype goes.
 
 So genes can be represented by letters with capital letters being used for dominant genes and lowercase letters used for recessive genes.
 
 Since offspring get one copy of each gene from each of their parents you can have 3 different genotypes. AA means a dominant form of the gene represented by the letter a came from each parent. aa means that each parent gave a recessive form of the gene and Aa or aA means one parent gave a dominant gene and the other gave a recessive one.
 
 Assuming that heterosexuality is the dominant trait and homosexuality is the recessive trait, two AA parents can have only AA offspring and 100% of such offspring have a dominant phenotype and would be heterosexual. Two AA parents, i.e., two totally heterosexual parents can only have children that display heterosexual behavior.
 
 Two aa parents can have only aa offspring and 100% of their offspring have the recessive genotype so the mating of two Sodomites can produce only Sodomite children- but this is impossible in nature since humans reproduce only sexually.
 
 An AA parent mating with an aa parent gives only Aa offspring and 100% of the offspring have a dominant phenotype while also being a carrier for the recessive gene.
 
 Mating an Aa parent with another Aa parent can give AA offspring 1/4 of the time; Aa offspring 1/2 of the time and aa offspring 1/4 of the time. This would mean that at least 25% of the human population should be homosexual.
 
 So homosexual offspring can only come through the mating of two parents that have the recessive homosexual gene. Either an aa must mate with an Aa and each mating event has a 1/2 chance of producing a homosexual offspring; or two Aa parents must mate and each mating event has only a 1/4 chance of producing a homosexual offspring. So in a population of randomly-mating humans with an equal frequency of A and a genes the number of homosexuals should be somewhere between 25% and 50%. 
 
 Mendel's laws can only predict the probable offspring for individual mating events. In order to explain the frequency of homosexuals in the entire human population you must use the Hardy-Weinberg law. And fortunately for politics (and unfortunately for Sodomites with a political agenda) Hardy-Weinberg uses mathematics to describe what a population's collective genetics mean.
 
 For a single gene with a dominant and recessive form the frequency with which the dominant form, A, is found in a population is designated as p, and q is used to represent the frequency of the recessive form, a. The combined frequencies, p + q, always equals 1, i.e., 100% of a stable randomly mating population will have either an A or an a gene.
 
 So, the frequency of the AA genotype is p-squared, and the frequency of the aa genotype is q-squared. And the frequency of the Aa genotype is 2pq.
 
 Given the number of heterosexuals in the human population (the total number of AA and Aa individuals) and the biggest estimate I have ever seen claimed for the number of homosexuals in the human population (the 10% claimed by politically-active Sodomites) the frequencies predicted by Mendel and Hardy-Weinberg don't match the number that has supposedly been observed in the real world- meaning that there is no genetic basis for homosexuality.

 No. Verifiable statistics regarding the religious beliefs/practices of Americans are pretty much impossible to obtain.  Actually, no. I am hesitant to bother explaining this to someone who obviously is hostile to Christians, but self-proclaimed Christians don't all worship the same god or use the same Bible.
 
 The Roman Catholic Bible has books that are not included in the Protestant Bible. And then groups like the Mormons and Christian Scientists have their own holy books that they use in addition to the Bible.
 
 And among Protestants you have the issue of Bible translation. Some Baptists use only the King James of 1611 (and some of these Baptists don't consider themselves to be Protestant). Other Protestants use any number of other translations despite the fact that these translations are based on Bible manuscripts that don't agree with each other and don't agree with the manuscripts that the King James was translated from.
 
 Furthermore, Roman Catholics venerate saints and the Virgin Mary that gave birth to Christ. Protestants do not venerate anyone but God and (as far as I know) they don't accept the Catholic idea that Mary remained a virgin for her entire life. Protestants and Catholics are Trinitarians, but Mormons, Jehovah's Witnesses and Seventh Day Adventists are not.

 That's not what I said. Protestants and Roman Catholics have beliefs that are mutually exclusive of each other. You cannot be a Protestant at the same time you are a Catholic and you cannot be a Catholic at the same time you are a Protestant- so they cannot both be Christian.
 
 
 
 Would it do any good?
 
 
 
 What you don't understand is that things have been added to these creeds over time. And people like Mormons and Jehovah's Witnesses do not accept these creeds.

 
 The only thing added to the creeds is the filioque clause in the Nicene Creed as used in western churches, everything else is as it was when they were written. As for being both Catholic and Protestant, that's precisely what Anglicanism is - both Catholic and reformed is the phrasing used. To be a Christian is to be a follower of the way as described by Jesus Christ (the first Christians were called followers of the way). That doesn't mean you have to agree on everything that other followers do. There is, no doubt, a correct understanding of the nature of God, but having a slightly incorrect understanding (as we all do, given the complexity and mystery of God) does not prevent one following the way. You're correct that there are heterodox groups that reject what the Christian church has traditionally believed, as outlined in the creeds, but even in the US they make a up a tiny fraction of those who call themselves Christians (1.7% of the population is Mormon, for example).

[QUOTE=Jo Bennett;408424][QUOTE=flaja;408406]
